column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=CHAPTER I
#Text=“ Such a charming lady in a grey silk dress and a hand as white as snow .
#Text=She looked at me through such funny glasses on the end of a long handle .
#Text=A very great lady but her voice was as kind as the voice of a saint .
#Text=I have never seen anything like that .
#Text=She made me feel so timid . ”
#Text=The voice uttering these words was the voice of Therese and I looked at her from a bed draped heavily in brown silk curtains fantastically looped up from ceiling to floor .
#Text=The glow of a sunshiny day was toned down by closed jalousies to a mere transparency of darkness .
#Text=In this thin medium Therese ’s form appeared flat , without detail , as if cut out of black paper .
#Text=It glided towards the window and with a click and a scrape let in the full flood of light which smote my aching eyeballs painfully .
#Text=In truth all that night had been the abomination of desolation to me .

#Text=After wrestling with my thoughts , if the acute consciousness of a woman ’s existence may be called a thought , I had apparently dropped off to sleep only to go on wrestling with a nightmare , a senseless and terrifying dream of being in bonds which , even after waking , made me feel powerless in all my limbs .

#Text=I lay still , suffering acutely from a renewed sense of existence , unable to lift an arm , and wondering why I was not at sea , how long I had slept , how long Therese had been talking before her voice had reached me in that purgatory of hopeless longing and unanswerable questions to which I was condemned .
#Text=It was Therese ’s habit to begin talking directly she entered the room with the tray of morning coffee .
#Text=This was her method for waking me up .

#Text=I generally regained the consciousness of the external world on some pious phrase asserting the spiritual comfort of early mass , or on angry lamentations about the unconscionable rapacity of the dealers in fish and vegetables ; for after mass it was Therese ’s practice to do the marketing for the house .
#Text=As a matter of fact the necessity of having to pay , to actually give money to people , infuriated the pious Therese .

#Text=But the matter of this morning ’s speech was so extraordinary that it might have been the prolongation of a nightmare : a man in bonds having to listen to weird and unaccountable speeches against which , he does n’t know why , his very soul revolts .
#Text=In sober truth my soul remained in revolt though I was convinced that I was no longer dreaming .
#Text=I watched Therese coming away from the window with that helpless dread a man bound hand and foot may be excused to feel .
#Text=For in such a situation even the absurd may appear ominous .
#Text=She came up close to the bed and folding her hands meekly in front of her turned her eyes up to the ceiling .
#Text=“ If I had been her daughter she could n’t have spoken more softly to me , ” she said sentimentally .
#Text=I made a great effort to speak .
#Text=“ Mademoiselle Therese , you are raving . ”
#Text=“ She addressed me as Mademoiselle , too , so nicely .
#Text=I was struck with veneration for her white hair but her face , believe me , my dear young Monsieur , has not so many wrinkles as mine . ”
#Text=She compressed her lips with an angry glance at me as if I could help her wrinkles , then she sighed .
#Text=“ God sends wrinkles , but what is our face ? ”
#Text=she digressed in a tone of great humility .
#Text=“ We shall have glorious faces in Paradise .
#Text=But meantime God has permitted me to preserve a smooth heart . ”
#Text=“ Are you going to keep on like this much longer ? ”
#Text=I fairly shouted at her .
#Text=“ What are you talking about ? ”
#Text=“ I am talking about the sweet old lady who came in a carriage .
#Text=Not a fiacre .
#Text=I can tell a fiacre .
#Text=In a little carriage shut in with glass all in front .
#Text=I suppose she is very rich .
#Text=The carriage was very shiny outside and all beautiful grey stuff inside .
#Text=I opened the door to her myself .
#Text=She got out slowly like a queen .
#Text=I was struck all of a heap .
#Text=Such a shiny beautiful little carriage .
#Text=There were blue silk tassels inside , beautiful silk tassels . ”
#Text=Obviously Therese had been very much impressed by a brougham , though she did n’t know the name for it .
#Text=Of all the town she knew nothing but the streets which led to a neighbouring church frequented only by the poorer classes and the humble quarter around , where she did her marketing .

#Text=Besides , she was accustomed to glide along the walls with her eyes cast down ; for her natural boldness would never show itself through that nun-like mien except when bargaining , if only on a matter of threepence .
#Text=Such a turn-out had never been presented to her notice before .
#Text=The traffic in the street of the Consuls was mostly pedestrian and far from fashionable .
#Text=And anyhow Therese never looked out of the window .
#Text=She lurked in the depths of the house like some kind of spider that shuns attention .
#Text=She used to dart at one from some dark recesses which I never explored .
#Text=Yet it seemed to me that she exaggerated her raptures for some reason or other .
#Text=With her it was very difficult to distinguish between craft and innocence .
